title: Journal of a tour through the Highlands of Scotland during the summer of MDCCCXXIX.
author: Botfield, Beriah
snippet: Mr, Nairne having recently discovered ameteoric stone among the ruins of Macbeth's Castle upon the hill ofDunsinnan, it has heen conjectured that it wa.s the true Palladium,there concealed from motives of policy by the usurper Macbeth,who substituted the present stone in its place ; but it does not sollow, even according to Fluellens Logic, that, because there is ablack stone at Dunsinnan there must have been one at Dunstaffnage.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
author: Todd, George Eyre.
snippet: From Dunsinnan it is but a feAv miles along the foot of the SidlaAvhills to Scone, and there again the pedestrian finds himself treadingupon strangely suggestive soil.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
author: Todd, George Eyre.
snippet: Once on Dunsinnan the fact of the double rampart Avould immediatelyimpress itself, and the further fact Avould become evident, that Birnamis not only visible from Dunsinnan, but is the most conspicuous objectof the landscape; Avhile some local cicerone Avould be sure to furnish theaccount of Macbeth's end current in the neighbourhood.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
author: Todd, George Eyre.
snippet: The road betweenPerth and Aberdeen Avhich the players must have folioAved lay Avithinthree miles of Dunsinnan, and one of the company, interested in thestory of the spot, may* very Avell have stepped aside to examine the scene.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
author: Todd, George Eyre.
snippet: Shakespeare, again, implies the somewhatpeculiar circumstance that Birnam can be seen from Dunsinnan.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
author: Todd, George Eyre.
snippet: But the histories relate that Macbethescaped from Dunsinnan, and made a further stand in the forest ofLumphanan, on the Dee.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
author: Todd, George Eyre.
snippet: Sidlaw Hills, is fifteen miles, and from the massive castle ruins on Dunsinnan, Birnam can just be seen.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
